Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: A Surface Acoustic Wave Based Ion Source
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will improve the performance of Surface Acoustic Wave Nebulization (SAWN) for use with mass spectrometers. Mass spectrometry (MS) is a widely used method to measure chemical composition; i.e. what chemical elements (e.g. C, N, S, O) are in a given molecule and how are they configured structurally. For MS analysis chemical compounds must be moved from the laboratory environment to the MS instrument by a method known as ionization. The development of SAWN provides a novel means to ionize chemical compounds that combines the performance characteristics of electrospray ionization (ESI) with the ease of use of matrix assisted laser desorption ionization (MALDI).

The broader/commercial impacts of this research are to position SAWN as a commercially viable ionization platform. The simplicity of SAWN, which operates on a planar surface with very low energy requirements and no moving parts, will provide a platform that sits between the two popular methods ESI and MALDI. The simplicity in design makes it more readily deployable to mobile laboratories than ESI and MALDI. An improved SAWN device will have a broad impact on multiple areas of science that rely on MS for quantitative and qualitative measurements, ranging from food science, forensics, life sciences and clinical medicine. Specifically, the lower level of energy required by SAWN to produce ions means that it is better able to detect chemical compounds that are destroyed by ESI and MALDI.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mass spectrometry is a widely used method for determining the composition, quantity, and structure of molecules. For example, clinicians often employ mass spectrometry to identify molecules that can signify the presence of disease. Scientists perform mass spectrometry to study molecules in biology, chemistry, and other diverse areas. Pharmaceutical companies regularly use mass spectrometry to determine the efficacy of a given drug. In order for molecules to be seen by mass spectrometry, they must first undergo a process called ionization. During ionization, a charge is added to the molecule in accordance with the ionization method being used. Currently, the two most commonly used forms of ionization are electrospray ionization (ESI) and matrix-assisted laser desorption (MALDI). Despite the widespread adoption of ESI and MALDI there are significant problems that still exist for each, and therefore ionization remains an active field of research. For instance, despite both techniques being considered soft, i.e. neither technique puts much energy into the molecule; there are still numerous classes of molecules that are fragmented using these ionization methods. Additionally, ESI requires an expert to operate and uses small capillaries that are prone to clogging and breaking. A technique developed recently surface acoustic wave nebulization (SAWN) was developed that generated ions from a flat crystal surface. SAWN operates by a series of patterning electrodes onto the surface of a piezoelectric crystal. These waves can then be used to nebulize liquid samples. In this way, there are no capillaries to clog and the unparalleled ease-of-use meant SAWN was widely accessible. It was also shown that SAWN was capable of preserving chemical structure where ESI could not due to the fact it imparted less energy into the molecule. Despite these advances SAWN still suffered from poor sensitivity.

In this work, we demonstrated the use of a new type of SAWN chip based on standing waves. We referred to this version of the SAWN chip as standing wave SAWN (SW-SAWN). Like ESI, SAWN generates small droplets of molecules that are analyzed by the mass spectrometer. With the original SAWN chip, the droplets being produced are large and are not properly evaporated by the mass spectrometer. SW-SAWN produces droplets that are smaller than the original SAWN device by changing the type of wave used to nebulize. We showed in our research here that a dramatic increase in signal is observed with SW-SAWN. Without this improvement in signal, SAWN will never expand beyond the laboratory. This technical achievement makes SAWN competitive against both ESI and MALDI, which currently dominate the ionization market. While SW-SAWN provides a large increase in sensitivity, the act of running samples in SAWN remained a manual process. To address this problem we demonstrated another type of SAWN device based on circular electrodes. We refer to this type of nebulizer as ring-SAWN. In our research we demonstrated that ring-SAWN, do to its circular nature, is very effective at keeping the sample constrained in a single location. Furthermore, due to the geometry of ring-SAWN, the amount of physical space required to make the nebulizer is significantly smaller than either the original SAWN configuration or the SW-SAWN. With the small features of the ring-SAWN we were able to demonstrate a compact 2x2 array of ring-SAWN nebulizers. Here, each array member was addressed discretely by a custom electronics and software package we created. The advancements made here will be used to develop a fully automated high-throughput version of SAWN. This will allow scientists, clinicians, and other SAWN users to operate SAWN in the high-throughput manner that is expected with mass spectrometry. Lastly, we demonstrated a series of improvements for the current versions of SAWN that make them user-operable in a mass sp...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Mass spectrometry is a widely used method for determining the composition, quantity, and structure of molecules. For example, clinicians often employ mass spectrometry to identify molecules that can signify the presence of disease. Scientists perform mass spectrometry to study molecules in biology, chemistry, and other diverse areas. Pharmaceutical companies regularly use mass spectrometry to determine the efficacy of a given drug. In order for molecules to be seen by mass spectrometry, they must first undergo a process called ionization. During ionization, a charge is added to the molecule in accordance with the ionization method being used. Currently, the two most commonly used forms of ionization are electrospray ionization (ESI) and matrix-assisted laser desorption (MALDI). Despite the widespread adoption of ESI and MALDI there are significant problems that still exist for each, and therefore ionization remains an active field of research. For instance, despite both techniques being considered soft, i.e. neither technique puts much energy into the molecule; there are still numerous classes of molecules that are fragmented using these ionization methods. Additionally, ESI requires an expert to operate and uses small capillaries that are prone to clogging and breaking. A technique developed recently surface acoustic wave nebulization (SAWN) was developed that generated ions from a flat crystal surface. SAWN operates by a series of patterning electrodes onto the surface of a piezoelectric crystal. These waves can then be used to nebulize liquid samples. In this way, there are no capillaries to clog and the unparalleled ease-of-use meant SAWN was widely accessible. It was also shown that SAWN was capable of preserving chemical structure where ESI could not due to the fact it imparted less energy into the molecule. Despite these advances SAWN still suffered from poor sensitivity. In this work, we demonstrated the use of a new type of SAWN chip based on standing waves. We referred to this version of the SAWN chip as standing wave SAWN (SW-SAWN). Like ESI, SAWN generates small droplets of molecules that are analyzed by the mass spectrometer. With the original SAWN chip, the droplets being produced are large and are not properly evaporated by the mass spectrometer. SW-SAWN produces droplets that are smaller than the original SAWN device by changing the type of wave used to nebulize. We showed in our research here that a dramatic increase in signal is observed with SW-SAWN. Without this improvement in signal, SAWN will never expand beyond the laboratory. This technical achievement makes SAWN competitive against both ESI and MALDI, which currently dominate the ionization market. While SW-SAWN provides a large increase in sensitivity, the act of running samples in SAWN remained a manual process. To address this problem we demonstrated another type of SAWN device based on circular electrodes. We refer to this type of nebulizer as ring-SAWN. In our research we demonstrated that ring-SAWN, do to its circular nature, is very effective at keeping the sample constrained in a single location. Furthermore, due to the geometry of ring-SAWN, the amount of physical space required to make the nebulizer is significantly smaller than either the original SAWN configuration or the SW-SAWN. With the small features of the ring-SAWN we were able to demonstrate a compact 2x2 array of ring-SAWN nebulizers. Here, each array member was addressed discretely by a custom electronics and software package we created. The advancements made here will be used to develop a fully automated high-throughput version of SAWN. This will allow scientists, clinicians, and other SAWN users to operate SAWN in the high-throughput manner that is expected with mass spectrometry. Lastly, we demonstrated a series of improvements for the current versions of SAWN that make them user-operable in a mass spectrometry facility.
